It about time!  I don't care how old he is.  Those miners won't have another month.   He should do 31 years for each one.

"I wouldn't sell my sperm for even millions of dollars if I didn't like the receiver."
Your comment would imply a private transaction but in a typical one the sperm donors deposit is merely stored frozen with a catalog reference to the attributes of the donor and the donor and the recipient will never know who either party is.

Based on the uniqueness of the provider the price may vary from a few thousand dollars to infinity. Women have been shortchanged throughout history. This is just another example for the same. I wouldn't sell my sperm for even millions of dollars if I didn't like the receiver.

Wealthy and upper middle class women do not donate their eggs. This is a terrible instance of better off women (and men) exploiting poor women for a piece of their bodies. The fact that women are exploiting other women doesn't make it noble - the opposite, actually. Egg donation is not like sperm donation - it requires stimulation with hormones and surgery. Except for those rare cases where family members are involved this ought to be outlawed. We wouldn't let people sell a kidney because they an extra one - why this?   It makes me ill as a woman and a feminist to see this become mainstream.

You actually really think that someone otherwise obeying the law and playing an upstanding role in society and their community while helping their kids with homework at night or struggling to save enough to buy a house. Is the NYT editorial board aware that the May 28, 2015 report of the Center for Immigration Studies indicates that according to ICE records, that agency admits to releasing 30,558 convicted criminal aliens in 2014. Convictions included 175 homicides, 373 sexual assaults, 186 kidnappings, among the 79,059 crimes. What does it say about a society that ignores and protects such behavior? No wonder people feel safer owning guns.

Thomas: That seems like an unfair response to Bill, in my opinion. Of course we have each and all broken laws at one time or another. But this question is not about the law-BREAKERS as much as it is about the law-ENFORCERS. How can it possibly become public policy to allow and encourage eleven million law breakers to come right on in? Don't we have enough law breakers here already? As a liberal, I am concerned that I cannot seem to understand or accept the idea of amnesty--especially when there are millions of earnest and honest emigrants jumping through all the hoops, struggling with all the required documentation, while waiting their turn to join us. All are welcome; that is not my problem. But, cheating, cutting in line, and the arrogance and attitude of entitlement is a denial of reality and a rejection of American laws and law enforcement. Why should we accept that?

Why is the deportation of illegal immigrants unjust? Can I openly break the law and gain sanctuary uncertain cities? The NYT editorial board is clearly out of touch. The immigration laws are Federal Laws that should be enforced. Who gets to pick and chose what laws they will obey? Apparently only illegal immigrants.

Our average top 350 US CEO's annual compensation as measured in 2013 dollars, rose from $819,000 in 1965 to $15,610,000 in 2013, while the average non-supervisory worker's earnings rose from $39,000 to $52,000 over that same period as measured in those same 2013 dollars. The top tier income tax rate in 1965 was 70%. In 2013 it was 39.6%.  I agree with those tea party economists who long for good ole' 1960's when the national debt was only 58% of GDP. I'll bet we could achieve that in a few short years at current spending levels if we once again taxed the top tier earners at 70%. (Interestingly, those 1965 top 350 CEOs were about $650,000 shy of making the top tax bracket - as measured in today's inflation adjusted dollars.  While today's top 350 CEOs annually knock down $14,600,000 more than lower realm of the uppermost tax tier. The current top tier tax bracket now begins at just over $400,000 in today's dollars. In 1965 as measured in 1965 dollars, the top tier started at $200,000, which is equivalent to $1,400,000 in today's dollars.  $400,000 in today's dollars equals $52,000 in 1965 dollars, which was taxed at 52% then. In 1960 at the end of the Dwight D. Eisenhauer presidency, the top tier tax was 92%.

I guess I'm part of the top 1% based on the author's standards. Like so many others have said, I went to school studied hard and then graduated with a good degree. Now I work hard and make good money. Because I'm responsible, have no children I am taxed heavily in the 40% range. On top of that I also support my sister who is in school and my retired mother who get $1,000 from social security (she can't work because if she makes over $15k she loses her social security benefits). I'm also repaying a mountain of student loans, paying a ridiculous premium every month for health insurance and am saving for my own retirement. This set up doesn't seem fair to me.

In Europe where the taxes are this exorbitant I would have none of these expenses. My sister's education would be free. My mother would be retired comfortably. I would have no student loans and my health insurance and retirement would be set. That seems fair to me.

If you want to tax me then you need to provide me with more services.

One trillion = 1,000,000,000,000; or 1 followed by 12 zeros. One billion = 1,000,000,000; or 1 followed by 9 zeros. One trillion = one thousand billion, not one billion billion. Our national debt is reported in this article as 22 trillion, or 22 thousand billion, not 22 billion billion.  A large number of dollars, none the less.  Accounting  for inflation,  today's 22 trillion dollar debt would be  $2,912,437,660,000 (or, 2.9 trillion) in 1965 dollars. This is just about 9 times the actual debt on June 30th 1965 (which was 317,273,898,983.64 dollars according to the US Treasury).  Over that same time frame, our GDP has increased 4 fold, from 4.1 trillion dollars in 1965 to 16.3 trillion in 2015, as measured in equal value dollars.

1,000 billion = 1 trillion......sorry, but your math is horribly off. You should have actually stopped right at the beginning of your sequence: "...if we start counting beyond the hundreds of billions we save from the strategy espoused in this article, we eventually get to thousands of billions".  Sounds like trillions to me, so no need to go further.

It may sound impressive to say taxing the top 1% of income earners in the US would produce hundred of billions, but we are 22 trillion dollars in debt. So, let's count a bit--if we start counting beyond the hundreds of billions we save from the strategy espoused in this article, we eventually get to thousands of billions, then to tens of thousands of billions, followed by hundreds of thousands of billions, to millions of billions, to tens of millions of billions, to hundreds of millions of billions, to thousands of millions of billions, to tens of thousands of millions of billions, to hundreds of thousands of millions of billions to finally arrive at one trillion (then do that 22 more times).

Unlike the claim made by Ms. Cohen, it appears that taxing the top 1% really doesn't amount to that much.

I think the vast majority of people work "very hard" all their lives.  Some are are lucky, others not.  Some work much harder than you and your wife simply to eat and survive.  Warren Buffet was astute enough to observe that as bright and hard working as he has been, were he born in a ghetto in Quito, he would not have created Berkshire Hathaway. Others are vain enough to believe that if they were born into opportunity and took full advantage of it,  that they must deserve every last drop of it. I would suggest that as a nurse and an engineer knocking down income in the top percentile, you are simply overpaid.
MD, here's a question for you. How does the number of apples that another person has change the morality of stealing one of them?  Not the practicality, but the morality.

My wife and I have worked very hard, she is a nurse and I'm an engineer. We started with little and after decades of hard work we are considered in the top 1 percent of earners in the U.S. We pay 33 percent to the federal government 9 percent to NYS, $35k in property tax, sales tax of 8 percent, gasoline tax. When you add it all up, we are paying over 50 percent of our income in taxes. Isn't that enough? We are at the point of saying we have enough invested, stop working moving to Naples Florida and just enjoying life.

I feel we are working harder and harder to earn 45 cents on every dollar we make. Just feels like we are paying more than our fair share.

re "The Fed and Obama have created a phony economy with near-zero interest rates. "

No president in US history has ever been handed such a mess as Obama inherited from the disastrous conservative Bush administration in which the economy was in absolute free fall, the GDP plunging 9% in just one quarter. That's equivalent to THREE years of robust growth literally wiped out in three months! US foreign policy was in a shambles, and 750,000 jobs were being lost each and every month.

Just go back to Sept. of 2008 to honestly admit that Obama & company have performed a veritable miracle; we are much better off today than we should have been able to expect we would be, when viewed from the bottom of that deep chasm 7 years ago.

Many of those commenting confuse income with wealth. The article deals only with income. Those in the top tier differ from year to year. Wealthy tend to stay wealthy. Any proposals for confiscating the wealth of the wealthy?

What is fascinating is how many Democrats propose new entitlement programs when the USA is so heavily in debt. Wait until interest rates rise again, and observe how large a segment of tax receipts will have to be devoted to debt service. The Fed and Obama have created a phony economy with near-zero interest rates.

Yes - I believe that is the effect - that when high salaries are taxed at 75% the incentive to take a high salary now is replaced with one to invest in ones business, building value for the long term.

Note the arguments: if we only took more of other people's money away, we could then spend it on ourselves!! Oh, joy!! Lots of free stuff.

(Never mind that we're blowing through $500B in borrowed money every year, such that if we did decide to raise taxes, if it actually raised revenue, it should certainly not go to new spending.)

But the number one thing we could do if we hike taxes, of course, is destroy the economy.

Picketty understands. He notes that massive taxes on wealth and income don't redistribute it, they destroy it. And he's down with that, because he'd prefer that the wealth not exist at all than that it be distributed "unfairly".

So, all the leftists greedily rubbing their hands together at the thought of a huge pile of other people's money to spend should understand -- not that they will, but that they should -- that there will little to spend this year and less next, as the economy contracts, and wealth and income vanish.

Tax something, you get less of it.

It's tough to measure which is worse: the economic ignorance of the left, or its base envy. Either way, it does not bode well for the country.

Folks act like income inequality is something new.  Since the dawn of human civilization, mankind has found novel ways to keep wealth and the levers that control wealth creation in few  hands as possible and will continue to do so.  The 99% has been bamboozled into thinking that the poor and middle class should pay the brunt of taxes.  Is there government waste and mishandling of our tax revenue, yes of course.  Republicans would have you believe smaller government is the answer...the thing is that it's 2015 not 1790.  I agree that government can be more efficient and cutting out duplicate governmental agencies but taking a meat cleaver to the federal budget serves no one.  The federal government do things that at the state and local level can't be achieved.  Taxes are inherently unfair to begin because by its very nature it pits groups against each other and forces politicians to prioritize one group over another.  The wealthy will always win out over the long term because they can buy the politicians that shares the same worldview on taxes...i.e. they pay nothing while the rest of us pay the lionshare.

"Raising taxes to punish a lifetime of hard work to be successful is wrong."  I'm near the 1% and I don't feel like paying taxes is punishment; it means I can afford paying high taxes.  I much prefer be a member of the 1% and pay taxes than be in the 50th percentile and pay lower taxes.

State and local taxes are commonly deducted from income used to calculate Federal income taxes, so the impact of such taxes is lessened for high income taxpayers.   This tax benefit is in effect a subsidy by low and no income tax states to high income tax states.  The author might have profitably examined how much new revenue would be generated by eliminating this deduction.  Arguably, if taxpayers (and state lawmakers) were required to pay state income taxes with no deductibility, voters in states such as New York and California would pay more attention to state budgets and their effect on taxes.

Interesting article, whose main point may be:

"The top 1 percent on average . . . pay roughly a third of their incomes to the federal government, according to a Treasury Department analysis that takes into account the entire menu of taxes—including income tax, payroll taxes that fund Medicare and Social Security, estate and gift taxes, excise and custom duties as well as investors’ share of corporate taxes."

My question would be: given the average and marginal income-tax rates in high-tax states like New York and California, what is the total (state and federal, and maybe local) percentage of income-tax and social program exactions on incomes there? Could it be 50% of income or more for high earners? Not sure.

I wonder if people would move out of New York and California to low or no income tax states if the total federal take, as defined in the article, approached 40% or 45%, up from its reported approximately 33%.

I'm leaving aside property-tax considerations in the comments above, but I and others think about our property tax when ruminating on how much we pay various governments each year. It would be good to get an estimate of total deductions from income under all categories of exaction by all levels of government.
Congrats on " finally" figuring this out. Im sure though, many would counter that the Fed is supposed to be independent. But it looks pretty suspicious to me too,

Carrie,

You're missing an important point. Even if the Fed is independent – as it's supposed to be – it's expected to consider the effect of its actions on the US economy (at least on jobs). So whether the Fed hates or loves the politicians in office at any given time, it's appropriate for the Fed to consider whether its boosting of interest rates will hamper the economy so much that the Fed ought not to do that. To be sure, if the Fed favors the political leaders in office at the moment, it will be more inclined not to raise interest rates. But even if it detests those political leaders, the Fed may decline to raise interest rates if doing so will hamper the economy. That's especially likely if the Fed knows that it, not the political leaders, will end up being blamed for hurting the economy.

Some Fed leaders pretty much ignore these considerations – Volcker, for example. But most of them want to be liked, just the same as elected politicians do.
What experience has led you to believe that the Federal Reserve has any concern over the cost of government?

I finally figured this out:

One big reason the Federal Reserve has declined to raise interest rates is that doing so would raise the rate on the gargantuan US debt. The US government owes $18 trillion. A 1% increase in annual interest rates would cost us an additional $180 billion every time that debt is rolled over.

The Federal Reserve has to consider what effect a rate increase would have on the economy. If it knows a !% increase in interest rates will add $180 billion annually to the cost of government, naturally it will incline toward not raising rates.

No, the wealthy are taking so much out of the economy the current tax structure is not reasonable.  When one person on Wall Street can make more than a school system, it is not good for the economy.  The wealthy don't invest in businesses to create jobs, they invest to make profits, which too often results in job consolidation and loss.  A fair share is not more than 20 times what the average person makes.  Then our economy would be stronger for everyone.

"All the Republican candidates share the party’s traditional opposition to raising taxes on the wealthy, arguing that it would ruin the economy by sopping up money that would otherwise be used to create jobs. Lowering taxes, they say, will unleash a torrent of economic activity that will in the long run spur growth and revenue."

Pure nonsense and lies. It would only be true of the wealthy spent all their money instead of hoarding it in off shore tax havens. Taxing the money and spending it is how you spur growth and revenue.

Dems want to spend, spend, spend...invest, invest, invest in the American people.
TP/GOP want to spend, spend, spend on Endless War Budget and then cut taxes on the wealthy and starve medicare and social security! WOW....now which Party is more responsible?
(By the way, 76 million babyboomers will reach 65 over the next 13 years. Social Security and Medicare must be supported). These programs, that have kept seniors out of extreme poverty were brought to us by Democrats!

The fact of the matter is that the deficit has declined from 10.1% of GDP the year Obama took office to 2.4% of GDP last fiscal year. Not only is that impressive deficit reduction, it's the fastest deficit reduction since the demobilization following WW2. That is faster deficit reduction than we experienced during the Clinton era. Blaming Obama for the debt - while ignoring how fast the annual deficit was reduced - is like blaming firefighters battling an immense wildfire for the acreage that burned "on their watch" while they put out the fire.

As for spending, that too has come down significantly, from 24.4% of GDP for Bush's last fiscal year to 20.6% of GDP last year. Anyone who knows the true history of federal spending and deficits in the U.S. knows that Democrats are the fiscally responsible ones. Who are the recent presidents who had the biggest annual increases in spending? Reagan, Bush Sr. and Bush Jr.

There is Almost no mention about the other side of the government ledger in this article, I.e. Spending.  It's obvious the intent among Democrats in DC is to spend, spend, spend, like a pig gorging himself at the trough.  Until the spending is brought under greater control, no amount of additional revenue generated from higher taxes will do a thing about our exploding national debt, which under Obama has increased from 65% of GDP to over 100% of GDP.
